Consider the following expression. AV_{[0.5,1]} = \frac{s(1)-s(0.5)}{1-0.5}
Compute the value of AV_{[0.5,1]}.
What does this value measure geometrically?

li.p: slope. The slope of the line between the points (0.5, s(0.5)) and (1, s(1)) .
curvature. The curvature of the graph of s on the interval 0.5 \leq t \leq 1 .
area. The area under the graph of s on the interval 0.5 \leq t \leq 1 .
distance. The distance between the points (0.5, s(0.5)) and (1, s(1)) .

statement.p: What does this value measure physically?

li.p: average velocity. The average velocity of the ball during the interval 0.5 \leq t \leq 1 .
distance. The distance that the ball travels during the interval 0.5 \leq t \leq 1 .
acceleration. The acceleration of the ball during the interval 0.5 \leq t \leq 1 .

statement.p: a) For each of the intervals, find the values of \Delta D and \Delta t between the indicated start and end times. Enter your answers in their respective columns in the table below.
b) Based on your results from (a) it follows that the average rate of change of D is constant, it does not depend over which interval of time you choose. What is the constant rate of change of D?

c) Which of the statements below CORRECTLY explains the significance of your answer to part (b)? Select ALL that apply (more than one may apply).
It is the acceleration of the car over the five hour time interval.
It is the average velocity of the car over the first two hours.
It is the slope of the line.
It is how far the car will travel in a half-hour.
It is the total distance the car travels in five hours.
It represents the car's velocity.
None of the above.

solution.p: a) Over the first interval t = 1.5 to t = 4.5, \Delta D = 225 - 75 = 150 and \Delta t = 4.5 - 1.5 = 3 .
Similarly, over the second interval t = 2 to t = 3.5, \Delta D = 175 - 100 = 75 and \Delta t = 3.5 - 2 = 1.5 .
Finally, over the last interval t = 1 to t = 3, \Delta D = 150 - 50 = 100 and \Delta t = 3 - 1 = 2 .
b) Notice that for each of the three intervals in (a) (as well as any other interval), \frac{ \Delta D }{ \Delta t} = 50.
c) There are three correct statements: It represents the car's velocity, it is the average velocity of the car over the first two hours, and it is the slope of the line.

Let \ f(x) = 9 - x^2.
a) Compute each of the following expressions and interpret each as an average rate of change:

b) Based on the graph sketched below, match each of your answers in (i) - (iii) with one of the lines labeled A - F. Type the corresponding letter of the line segment next to the appropriate formula. Clearly not all letters will be used.
(click on image to enlarge)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a)
i) \frac{f( 1 ) - f(0)}{ 1 - 0} = \frac{ 8 - 9 }{1 - 0} = \frac{ -1 }{ 1} = -1
ii) \frac{f( 3 ) - f( 1 ) }{ 3 - 1 } = \frac{ 0 - 8}{3 - 1} = \frac{ -8 }{ 2} = -4
iii) \frac{f( 3 ) - f(0)}{ 3 - 0} = \frac{ 0 - 9 }{ 3 - 0} = \frac{ -8 }{ 3} = -3
b) The formulas in parts (i), (ii), and (iii) represent the average rate of change of f(x) over the intervals 0 \leq x \leq 1 , 1 \leq x \leq 3 , and 0 \leq x \leq 3 respectively. Thus line segment D connecting the points (0, 9 ) and ( 1, 8 ) illustrates formula (i), line segment C connecting the points ( 1, 8 ) and ( 3, 0 ) illustrates formula (ii), and line segment B connecting the points (0, 9 ) and ( 3, 0 ) illustrates formula (iii).

statement.p: The table below gives the average temperature, T, at a depth d, in a borehole in Belleterre, Quebec.
Evaluate \Delta T / \Delta d on the following intervals
a) 50 \leq d \leq 125 \Delta T / \Delta d =
b) 125 \leq d \leq 250 \Delta T / \Delta d =
c) 75 \leq d \leq 125 \Delta T / \Delta d =
d) Which of the statements below correctly explains the significance of your answer to part (c)? Select all that apply (more than one may apply).

li.p: 0.004 is the slope of the graph of at d = 75.
Over the interval from 75 meters to 125 meters, the temperature changes on average at a rate of 0.004 degrees Celsius per meter.
The temperature changes by a total of 0.004 degrees Celsius when moving from a depth 75 meters to 125 meters.
The temperature is changing at a rate of 0.004 degrees Celsius per minute when the depth is 75 meters.
On average, the temperature is changing at a rate of 0.004 degrees Celsius per minute over the interval 75 \leq d \leq 125 .

solution.p: a) Over the interval d = 50 to d = 125, \Delta T = 5.30 - 5.20 = 0.0999999999999996 and \Delta d = 125 - 50 = 75 .
b) Over the interval d = 125 to d = 250, \Delta T = 6.50 - 5.30 = 1.2 and \Delta d = 250 - 125 = 125 .
Thus \Delta T / \Delta d = 1.2/125 .
c) Over the interval d = 75 to d = 125, \Delta T = 5.30 - 5.10 = 0.2 and \Delta d = 125 - 75 = 50 .
Thus \Delta T / \Delta d = 0.2/50 .
d) Only the statement Over the interval from 75 meters to 125 meters, the temperature changes on average at a rate of 0.004 degrees Celsius per meter is correct. All others are incorrect:
The statement, 0.004 is the slope of the graph of at d = 75, is incorrect since the average rate of change is the slope of the line segment connect the endpoints of the interval.

The statement, The temperature changes by a total of 0.004 degrees Celsius when moving from a depth 75 meters to 125 meters, is incorrect since the average rate of change is a ratio of the change in temperature divided by the change in depth (not just the total change in temperature.

The statement, On average the temperature is changing at a rate of 0.004 degrees Celsius per minute over the interval 75 \leq d \leq 125, is incorrect since the units must be degrees Celsius per meter (not minute).

The statement, The temperature is changing at a rate of 0.004 degrees Celsius per minute when the depth is 75 meters, is incorrect since the average rate of change averages the rates of change at every point in the interval. It is not the rate of the change at just the initial depth.

statement.p: Consider the graphs of f(x) and g(x) below:
For each interval given below, decide whether the average rate of change of f(x) or g(x) is greater over that particular interval.

row.cell: Which function has GREATER average rate of change?

var.name: AnSwEr0001
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0002
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0003
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0004
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0005
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the graph of g(x) is a line, its average rate of change is the same over all intervals. Since the graph of g(x) is going up, its average rate of change is always positive. The average rate of change of f(x) is clearly changing depending on the interval. If the slope of the line connecting the two endpoints of the interval on f(x) is going up and is steeper than the slope of g(x), then the average rate of change of f(x) will be greater over that interval. If the line connecting the two endpoints points on f(x) is less steep, horizontal, or going down, then the average rate of change of g(x) will greater over that interval. If the slope of the line connecting to endpoints of the interval on f(x) is the same as the slope of g(x), then the two average rates of change will be equal (such as the case for the interval 2.2 \leq x \leq 6.1. Based on this consideration, you should determine the following answers:
Interval Which function has GREATER average rate of change?
2.2 \leq x \leq 4 g
2.2 \leq x \leq 6.9 g
5.2 \leq x \leq 8 g
0 \leq x \leq 2.2 f
5.2 \leq x \leq 6.1 f

statement.p: Consider the graphs of f(x) and g(x) below:
For each interval given below, decide whether the average rate of change of f(x) is positive, negative, or zero over that particular interval.

row.cell: Sign of Average Rate of Change of f(x)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
The average rate of change of a function can be approximated graphically by looking at the steepness of the line segment connecting the two endpoints of the interval on the graph of f(x). If the line segment is going up, the average rate of change over the interval is positive. If the line segment is going down, the average rate of change over the interval is negative. If the line segment is horizontal, the average rate of change over the interval is zero. Based on this interpretation, you should determine the following answers:
Interval Sign of Average Rate of Change of f(x)
2.2 \leq x \leq 6.9 zero
0 \leq x \leq 2.2 positive
2.2 \leq x \leq 4 negative
5.2 \leq x \leq 6.9 zero
5.2 \leq x \leq 6.1 positive

A car is driven at an increasing speed, starting at noon. Which of the following could be a graph of the distance the car has traveled as a function of time past noon?
figure .

solution.p: SOLUTION

Because the car is driven at an increasing speed, the distance traveled for different time intervals of the same length must increase as time goes on. Therefore the slope of the graph of distance traveled must increase with increasing time, and must be 4.

Use the figure below, which gives a graph of the function f(x), to give values for the indicated limits. If a limit does not exist, enter DNE.
(a) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow -2} f(x) =
(b) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 0} f(x) =
(c) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 2} f(x) =
(d) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 3} f(x) =

solution.p: (a) As x approaches -2 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 6, so the limit appears to be about 6.

(b) As x approaches 0 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 10. (Recall that to find a limit, we are interested in what happens to the function near x but not at x.) The limit appears to be about 10.
(c) As x approaches 2 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 6 on one side of x = 2 and get closer and closer to 0 on the other side of x = 2. Thus the limit does not exist.
(d) As x approaches 3 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 4. (Again, recall that we don't care what happens right at x = 3.) The limit appears to be about 4.

Thus, as h\to 0 we have \frac{(3+h)^2- 9}{h} \to 6.

Let f(x) be the function whose graph is shown below.
Determine f'(a) for a = 1,2,4,7.

static.solution: f at x=a can be interpreted as the slope of the line tangent to the graph of y = f(x) at x=a. From the figure, we see that the graph of y = f(x) is a horizontal line (that is, a line with zero slope) on the interval 0 \le x \le 3. Accordingly, f'(1) = f'(2) = 0. On the interval 3 \le x \le 5, the graph of y = f(x) is a line of slope 1; thus, f'(4) = 1. Finally, the line tangent to the graph of y = f(x) at x=7 is horizontal, so f'(7) = 0.

statement.p: Consider the function y = f(x) graphed below.
Give the x-coordinate of a point where:
A. the derivative of the function is positive: x =
B. the value of the function is positive: x =
C. the derivative of the function is largest: x =
D. the derivative of the function is zero: x =
E. the derivative of the function is approximately the same as the derivative at x = 0.75 (be sure that you give a point that is distinct from x = 0.75!): x =

static.solution:
A. Recall that the derivative is positive when the function is increasing. So we're looking for a point on the graph where the function is increasing; one such point is x = 1.
B. The function is positive when the function is above the x-axis. One such point is x = 1.5.
C. The derivative of the function is largest when the function is increasing the fastest. This occurs at x \approx 3.25.
D. The derivative of the function is zero when the function has a horizontal tangent. One such point is x \approx 1.45.
E. Finally, we're looking for a point where the derivative is the same as the derivative at x = 0.75. This means that we want the slope of a tangent to the curve to be approximately the same as it is at x = 0.75. Such a point is x = 3.25.

statement.p: The figure below shows a function g(x) and its tangent line at the point B = (4.4,2.6). If the point A on the tangent line is (4.36,2.53), fill in the blanks below to complete the statements about the function g at the point B.

static.solution: B=(4.4,2.6) is on the graph of g, we have g(4.4)=2.6. The slope of the tangent line touching the graph at x=2 is given by \mbox{slope} = \frac{\mbox{rise}}{\mbox{run}} = \frac{2.6-2.53}{4.4-4.36} = 1.75. Thus, g'(4.4)=1.75.

statement.p: On a piece of paper, draw the graph of a continuous function y=f(x) that satisfies the following three conditions. f'(x) = 0\quad\mbox{for}\quad x \lt -4, f'(x) \lt 0\quad\mbox{for}\quad -4 \lt x \lt 4, f'(x) \lt 0\quad\mbox{for}\quad 4 \lt x

For 4 \lt x, use segment

static.solution: f'(x) = 0 for x \lt -4, the first segment must be 6. Similarly, because f'(x) \lt 0 for -4 \lt x \lt 4, the second segment must be one of 2, 7, or 8. And lastly, the third segment must be 2, 7, or 8.

statement.p: A child fills a pail by using a water hose. After finishing, the child plays in a sandbox for a while before tipping the pail over to empty it. If V(t) gives the volume of the water in the pail at time t, then the figure below shows V'(t) as a function of t.
At what time does the child:
A. Begin to fill the pail? t =
B. Finish filling the pail? t =
C. Tip the pail over? t =

p.em: (What would the graph of V'(t) look like if the child filled the pail by using a play shovel to repeatedly scoop water from a larger bucket and dump it in the pail instead of using a hose?)

static.solution: V'(t) becomes positive, which is when the volume of water in the pail starts increasing. This is at t = 3. The child finishes filling the pail when the volume stops increasing, which is at t = 9. The child tips the pail over when the volume of water in the pail start decreasing, which is where V'(t) first becomes negative, which is at t=14.

statement.p: Let f(x) = 3 + 6 \sqrt{x}. Then the expression \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} can be written in the form \frac{A}{\left(\sqrt{Bx + Ch} \right) + \left(\sqrt{x} \right)}, where A, B, and C are constants. (Note: It's possible for one or more of these constants to be 0.) Find the constants.
Use your answer from above to find \displaystyle{\lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h}}.
Finally, find each of the following:

solution.p: We simplify the expression \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} = \frac{3+6\sqrt{x+h}-(3+6\sqrt{x})}{h} by multiplying both numerator and denominator by the conjugate and simplifying.
Now, we can take \lim_{h\to 0} \frac{6}{\sqrt{x+h}+\sqrt{x}} = \frac{6}{2\sqrt{x}} .

solution.p: (a) As the cup of coffee cools, the temperature decreases, so f'(t) is negative.

(b) Since f'(t) = dH/dt, the units are degrees Celsius per minute (degC/min). The quantity f'(5) represents the rate at which the coffee is cooling, in degrees per minute, 5 minutes after the cup is put on the counter. Thus we can complete the statement:
At 5 minutes after the coffee was put on the counter, its temperature is 80 degC and will decrease by about 2.1 degC in the next 90 seconds.

(e) Suppose that Sam reads about f' in this study and draws the following conclusion: If Sam increases her average calorie intake from 2600 to 2630 calories per day, then her weight will increase by approximately 0.3 pounds.
Fill in the blanks below so that the equation supports her conclusion.

static.solution:
W=f(c) where W is weight in pounds and c is the number of Calories consumed per day:
(a) f(1600) = 150 means that consuming 1600 cal each day results in a weight of 150 lb (the units of 1600 are cal, and 150 lb).
(b) f'(2000)=0 means that consuming 2000 cal each day causes neither weight gain nor loss (the units of the 2000 are cal, and 0 lb/cal).
(c) f^{-1}(157)=2300 means that a weight of 157 lb is caused by a consumption of 2300 cal each day (the units of 157 are lb, and 2300 cal).
(d) The units of dW/dc are lb/cal
(e) Based on Sam's conclusion, f'(2600) should equal \frac{\Delta W}{\Delta c} = \frac{0.3}{30} = 0.01.

statement.p: Let f(t) be the number of centimeters of rainfall that has fallen since midnight, where t is the time in hours. Match the following statements to their interpretations, given below.

static.solution:
(a) f(7)=3.1: at 7 AM, 3.1 centimeters of rain have fallen.
(b) f^{-1}(7)=8: 7 centimeters of rain have fallen 8 hours after midnight.
(c) f'(7)=0.1: at 7 AM, the rain is falling at a rate of 0.1 cm/hr, so approximately 0.0017 cm of rain falls between 7 AM and 7:01 AM.
(d) (f^{-1})'(7)=3: when 7 centimeters of rain have fallen, it is accumulating at a rate of 1/3 cm/hr, so it takes approximately 18 min for the total accumulation to go from 7 to 7.1 cm .

statement.p: Suppose that f is given for x in the interval [0,12] by
A. Estimate f'(2) using the values of f in the table.
B. For what values of x does f'(x) appear to be positive?

p.em: (Give your answer as an interval or a list of intervals, e.g.,
or

statement.p: C. For what values of x does f'(x) appear to be negative?

p.em: (Give your answer as an interval or a list of intervals, e.g.,
or

solution.p: A. We could use the interval to the left or right of x = 2 to estimate the derivative, or we could average the two. We do the last of these here. For the interval to the left, we have f'(2) \approx \frac{f(2) - f(0)}{2-0} = \frac{-13 + 16}{2} = \frac{3}2. For that to the right, f'(2) \approx \frac{f(4) - f(2)}{4-2} = \frac{-12 + 13}{2} = \frac{1}2. Our estimate is therefore f'(2) \approx \frac12\left(\frac{3}2 + \frac{1}2\right) = 1.

B,C. We know that f'(x) is positive when f(x) is increasing and negative when f(x) is decreasing, so it appears that f'(x) is positive on the interval \left(0,4\right) and is negative on the interval \left(4,12\right).

statement.p: At exactly two of the labeled points in the figure below, which shows a function f, the derivative f' is zero; the second derivative f'' is not zero at any of the labeled points. Select the correct signs for each of f, f' and f'' at each marked point.

static.solution:
f is positive, negative, or zero by whether the point is plotted above, below, or on the x-axis. The sign of f' is determined by the slope of the function at the point: if the function is increasing, then f'>0; if it is decreasing, f'\lt 0, and if it is neither increasing nor decreasing, then f'=0. Similarly, the sign of f'' is determined by the concavity of the function: if the function is concave up, then f''>0, if it is concave down, f''\lt 0. This gives the table
Point A B C D E
f negative positive negative negative negative
f' zero positive negative zero positive
f'' positive negative positive positive positive

statement.p: Suppose that an accelerating car goes from 0 mph to 60.0 mph in five seconds. Its velocity is given in the following table, converted from miles per hour to feet per second, so that all time measurements are in seconds. (Note: 1 mph is 22/15 ft/sec.) Find the average acceleration of the car over each of the first two seconds.

average acceleration over the first second =
?

solution.p: To measure the average acceleration over an interval, we calculate the average rate of change of velocity over the interval. The units of acceleration are ft/s per second, or ft/s/s, written ft/s{}^2. \mbox{average acceleration for } 0\le t\le 1 = \frac{\mbox{Change in velocity}}{\mbox{Change in time}}, so, reading the velocities from the table, we have \frac{v(1) - v(0)}{1} = 30.00 - 0.00 = 30 \mbox{ ft/s}{}^2. Similarly, \mbox{avg accel for } 1\le t\le 2 = \frac{v(2) - v(1)}{2-1} = 52.00 - 30.00 = 22 \mbox{ ft/s}{}^2.

statement.p: Identify the graphs A (blue), B( red) and C (green) as the graphs of a function and its derivatives:
is the graph of the function
is the graph of the function's first derivative
is the graph of the function's second derivative

solution.p: SOLUTION
We can interpret f'(x) as the slope of the curve y = f(x) at the point (x, f(x)). Therefore f'(x) is negative when y = f(x) has negative slope and positive when y = f(x) has positive slope.
Similarly, f''(x) is negative when y= f'(x) has negative slope and positive when y = f'(x) has positive slope.
It follows that B is the graph of the function, A is the graph of the function's first derivative and C is the graph of the function's second derivative.

statement.p: Suppose that f(x) is a function with f(130) = 85 and f'(130) = 3. Estimate f(130.5).

static.solution: f(130) = 85 and f'(130) = 3 tell us that at x = 130, the value of the function is 85 and the function is increasing at a rate of 3 units for a unit increase in x. Since we increase x by 0.5 units in going from 130 to 130.5, the value of the function goes up by approximately 0.5 \cdot 3 = 1.5 units, so f(130.5) \approx 85 + 0.5 \cdot 3 = 85 + 1.5 = 86.5.

statement.p: Given that f(-6.2) = -2.7 and f(-6) = -6.4, approximate f'(-6.2).

static.solution:
Solution:
For small values of h, f'(c) \approx \frac{f(c+h) - f(c)}{h}. In this problem, c = -6.2, and h = -6 + 6.2 = 0.2. f'(-6.2) \approx \frac{f(-6) - f(-6.2)}{0.2} = \frac{-6.4 + 2.7}{0.2} = -18.5.

statement.p: Functions of the form f(x) = x^n, where n = 1, 2, 3, \ldots, are often called power functions.
(a) Use the limit definition of the derivative to find f'(x) for f(x)=x^2.
(b) Use the limit definition of the derivative to find f'(x) for f(x)=x^3.
(c) Use the limit definition of the derivative to find f'(x) for f(x)=x^4. (Hint: (a + b)^4 = a^4 + 4a^3 b + 6a^2 b^2 + 4ab^3 + b^4. Apply this rule to (x + h)^4 within the limit definition.)
(d) Based on your work in (a), (b), and (c), what do you conjecture is the derivative of f(x) = x^5?
(e) Conjecture a formula for the derivative of f(x) = x^n that holds for any positive integer n. That is, given f(x) = x^n where n is a positive integer, what do you think is the formula for f'(x)?

static.solution: f'(x) when f(x) = x^4. Using the limit definition of the derivative, \begin{align*} f'(x) \amp = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0 } \frac{(x+h)^4-x^4}{h} \\ \amp = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0 } \frac{x^4+4x^3h+6x^2h^2+4xh^3+h^4 -x^4}{h} \\ \amp = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0 } \frac{4x^3h+6x^2h^2+4xh^3+h^4}{h} \\ \amp = \lim_{h\rightarrow 0 } (4x^3+6x^2h+4xh^2+h^3) \\ \amp = 4x^3 \end{align*} Similarly, the derivative of x^3 is 3x^2 and the derivative of x^2 is 2x. Following the pattern, it is reasonable to conjecture that the derivative of x^5 is 5x^4, the derivative of x^{13} is 13x^{12}, and the derivative of x^n is nx^{n-1} for any positive integer n.

static.solution:
(1,5) is on the curve, we know f(1)=5. The point (1.1,5.4) is on the tangent line, so \hbox{Slope of tangent} = \frac{5.4-5}{1.1-1} = \frac{0.4}{0.1} = 4. Thus, f'(1)=4.
By the chain rule h'(1) = 2(f(1))\cdot f'(1) =2\cdot 5\cdot 4 = 40.
Because g(x) is the inverse function of f, we know that g(5) = 1. Then note that f(g(x)) = f(f^{-1}(x)) = x, so f(g(x)) = x. Differentiating both sides of the equation, f'(g(x))\cdot g'(x) = 1, so g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))}. Thus g'(5) = \frac{1}{f'(g(5))} = \frac{1}{f'(1)} = \frac1{4}.

solution.p: We differentiate implicitly with respect to x. This gives 5 x^{4} y - x^{5} \, \frac{dy}{dx} - 1 - 3 \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, or (x^{5}-3) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 1-5x^{4}y, and so \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{1 - 5 x^{4} y}{x^{5} - 3}.

solution.p: Differentiating with respect to x gives 2 x + 4 y + 4 x y' + 2y y'=0 so that y' = -\frac{2 x + 4 y}{4 x + 2 y}.
At the point (1,4) the slope is - \frac{2\cdot 1+4\cdot 4}{4\cdot 1+2\cdot 4} = -{\frac{3}{2}}.

statement.p: Find dy/dx by implicit differentiation.
Find dy/dx by implicit differentiation.

solution.p: We differentiate implicitly both sides of the equation with respect to x. \ln y + \frac xy \, \frac{dy}{dx} + 4 y^{3}\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{8}{x}, so \left( \frac{x}{y} + 4 y^{3} \right) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{8}{x} - \ln y, and thus \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{\frac{8}{x} - \ln y}{\frac{x}{y} + 4 y^{3}} = \frac{y\mathopen{}\left(8-x\ln\mathopen{}\left(y\right)\right)}{x\mathopen{}\left(x+4y^{4}\right)}.

statement.p: Find dy/dx in terms of x and y if \arcsin(x^{5} y) = x y^{5}.

static.solution: x. \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^{10} y^2}} (5 x^{4} y + x^{5} \frac{dy}{dx}) = y^{5} + 5 x y^{4} \frac{dy}{dx}, so, clearing the denominator, 5 x^{4} y + x^{5} \frac{dy}{dx} = \sqrt{1 - x^{10} y^2} (y^{5} + 5 x y^{4} \frac{dy}{dx}). Thus ( x^{5} - (5 x y^{4}) \sqrt{1 - x^{10} y^2} ) \frac{dy}{dx} = y^{5} \sqrt{1 - x^{10} y^2} - 5 x^{4} y, and finally \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{y^{5} \sqrt{1 - x^{10} y^2} - 5 x^{4} y}{x^{5} - (5 x y^{4}) \sqrt{1 - x^{10} y^2}}.

statement.p: Find the slope of the tangent to the curve \displaystyle y^2 = \frac{x^{3}}{xy + 6} at (6,3)

p.em: (Enter undef if the slope is not defined at this point.)

static.solution: \frac{dy}{dx}\big|_{(6,3)}. Implicit differentiation yields: 2y\frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{3 x^{2} (xy + 6) - x^{3}(x\frac{dy}{dx}+y)}{(xy + 6)^2}. Given the complexity of the above equation, we first want to substitute 6 for x and 3 for y (the coordinates of the point where we are constructing our tangent line), then solve for \frac{dy}{dx}. Substitution yields: 2(3) \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{3 (6^{2}) ((6)(3) + 6) - 6^{3}(6\frac{dy}{dx} + 3)}{((6)(3) + 6)^2}, or, 6 \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{2592 - 216 (6 \frac{dy}{dx} + 3)}{576}. Solving for \frac{dy}{dx}, we have: \frac{dy}{dx} \approx 0.4091.

solution.p: We differentiate both sides. g'(x)+x\cos(g(x))g'(x)+\sin(g(x))=2x Solving for g'(x) we get g'(x)\left[1+x\cos(g(x))\right]=2x-\sin(g(x)) and g'(x)=\frac{2x-\sin(g(x))}{1+x\cos(g(x))} Thus g'(4)=\frac{2\cdot4-\sin(g(4))}{1+4\cos(g(4))} =\frac{2\cdot4-\sin(0)}{1+4\cos(0)} = \frac{2\cdot4}{1+4}=1.6

Use implicit differentiation to find an equation of the tangent line to curve called the devil's curve,defined by y^{2}\mathopen{}\left(y^{2}-4\right) = x^{2}\mathopen{}\left(x^{2}-7\right), at the point \left(0,-2\right).
An equation of the tangent line to the devil's curve at the given point is .
(Be sure to enter the entire equation of the line, including the "y=".

solution.p: Writing the equation as y^4 - 4 y^2 = x^4 - 7 x^2, and then differentiating implicitly with respect to x, gives (4 y^3 - 8 y) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 4 x^3 - 14 x. If x = 0 and y = -2, then this last equation becomes -16 \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, \qquad \text{and so} \qquad \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, which means that the tangent line is horizontal. Therefore, the tangent line to the devil's curve at the point \left(0,-2\right) is defined by the equation y = -2.

Use a graph below of f(x) = \ln(5 x^2 + 1) to estimate the x-values of any critical points and inflection points of f(x).
critical points (enter as a comma-separated list): x =

Next, use derivatives to find the x-values of any critical points and inflection points exactly.
critical points (enter as a comma-separated list): x =

solution.p: SOLUTION
From the graph, we see that f(x) appears to have one critical point, at x=0, and two inflection points, one between 0 and 1 and the other between 0 and -1.
To find the critical points, we set f'(x) = 0. Since f'(x) = {2(5)x\over 5 x^2 + 1} = 0, there is one solution, x = 0. The only critical point is at x=0.

To find the inflection points, we find f''(x) and determine where it is zero. f''(x) = {10 (5 x^2 + 1) - 100 x^2\over(5 x^2+1)^2} = {10( 1 - 5 x^2 )\over(5 x^2+1)^2}. For this to be zero, we must have -1 + 5 x^2 = 0, or x = \pm 1/\sqrt{5}. There are exactly two inflection points, at x = -1/\sqrt{5} \approx -0.447 and x = 1/\sqrt{5} \approx 0.447.

static.solution: f'(x) = 4\left( 7 x^{6} (7 - x)^{6} - 6 x^{7}(7 - x)^{5} \right). Critical points are where this is zero, or, where 4 x^{6} (7-x)^{5} \left( 7(7 - x) - 6 x \right) = 4 x^{6} (7-x)^{5} \left( 49 - 13 x \right) = 0. So critical points are x = 0, x = 7 and x = 49/13. static.solution:
f'(x) we use the product and chain rules: f'(x) = a + (1)(\ln(bx)) + x (\frac1{bx}\cdot b) = a + \ln(bx) + 1. For x > 1 we know that \ln(bx) > 0, so, given that a > 0, f'(x) > 0 and we know that f(x) must be increasing.
Then f''(x) = \frac1x > 0, so the function must be concave up.

statement.p: Find constants a and b in the function f(x)=a x e^{b x} such that f(\frac{1}{9})=1 and the function has a local maximum at x=\frac{1}{9}.

static.solution:
f(x) = axe^{bx}, we have f'(x) = ae^{bx}+abxe^{bx}=ae^{bx}(1+bx). We want f(\frac{1}{9})=1, and since this is to be a maximum, we require f'(\frac{1}{9})=0. These conditions give
f(1/9) = \frac{a}{9} e^{b/9} = 1 and f'(1/9) = a e^{b/9}(1+b/9) = 0.
Since ae^{b/9} is non-zero, we can divide both sides of the second equation by ae^{b/9} to obtain 1 + \frac{b}{9} = 0. This implies b=-9. Plugging b=-9 into the first equation gives us a(\frac{1}{9})e^{-1}= 1, or a=9 e. How do we know we have a maximum at x=\frac{1}{9} and not a minimum? Since f'(x)=ae^{bx}(1+bx) = ()e^{-9 x}(1 - 9 x), and (9 e)e^{-9 x} is always positive, it follows that f'(x)>0 when x\lt \frac{1}{9} and f'(x)\lt 0 when x>\frac{1}{9}. Since f' is positive to the left of x=\frac{1}{9} and negative to the right of x = \frac{1}{9}, f(\frac{1}{9}) is a local maximum.

static.solution:
g'(x)=0: g'(x) = 3 - 2x = 0, so x = 1.5. Since g'(x)>0 for x\lt 1.5 and g'(x)\lt 0 for x>1.5, the critical point at x=1.5 is a local maximum.
As x\to\pm \infty, the value of g(x)\to-\infty. Thus, the local maximum at x=1.5 is a global maximum of g(1.5)=3 \cdot 1.5 - 1.5^2 - 15 = -12.75. There is no global minimum.

statement.p: Find the exact global maximum and minimum values of the function g(t) = 4 te^{-6 t} if t>0.
global maximum at t =
global minimum at t =

p.em: (Enter
if there is no global maximum or global minimum for this function.)

static.solution:
g'(t) = 4\cdot e^{-6 t} - 24 te^{-6 t} = 4 (1 - 6 t)e^{-6 t}, so the critical point is t=1/6.
Since g'(t)>0 for 0\lt t\lt 1/6 and g'(t)\lt 0 for t>1/6, the critical point is a local maximum.
As t\to\infty, the value of g(t)\to0, and as t\to0^+, the value of g(t)\to0. Thus, the local maximum at t=1/6 is a global maximum of g(1/6)={4\over 6} e^{-1} = {4\over 6 e}. In addition, the value of g(t) is positive for all t>0; it tends to 0 but never reaches 0. Thus, there is no global minimum.

statement.p: For some positive constant C, a patient's temperature change, T, due to a dose, D, of a drug is given by T = \left(\frac{C}{2} - \frac{D}{3}\right)D^2.
What dosage maximizes the temperature change?
The sensitivity of the body to the drug is defined as dT/dD. What dosage maximizes sensitivity?

solution.p: SOLUTION
We have T(D) = \left(\frac{C}{2} - \frac{D}{3}\right)D^2 = \frac{CD^2}{2}-\frac{D^3}{3}, and so \frac{dT}{dD} = CD-D^2 = D(C-D).
Since, by this formula, dT/dD is zero when D=0 or D=C, negative when D>C, and positive when D\lt C, we have (by the first derivative test) that the temperature change is maximized when D=C.

The sensitivity is dT/dD = CD-D^2; its derivative is d^2T/dD^2 = C-2D, which is zero if D= C/2, negative if D> C/2, and positive if D\lt C/2. Thus by the first derivative test the sensitivity is maximized at D=C/2.

According to U.S. postal regulations, the girth plus the length of a parcel sent by mail may not exceed 108 inches, where by "girth" we mean the perimeter of the smallest end. What is the largest possible volume of a rectangular parcel with a square end that can be sent by mail? Such a package is shown below, with x and y measured in inches. Assume y>x. What are the dimensions of the package of largest volume?
Find a formula for the volume of the parcel in terms of x and y.
Volume = cubic inches

The problem statement tells us that the parcel's girth plus length may not exceed 108 inches. In order to maximize volume, we assume that we will actually need the girth plus length to equal 108 inches. What equation does this produce involving x and y?
Equation:
Solve this equation for y in terms of x.
Find a formula for the volume V(x) in terms of x.
V(x) = cubic inches

What is the domain of the function V? Note that x must be positive and y>x; consider how these facts, and the constraint that girth plus length is 108 inches, limit the possible values for x. Give your answer using interval notation.
Domain:
Find the absolute maximum of the volume of the parcel on the domain you established above and hence also determine the dimensions of the box of greatest volume.
Maximum Volume = cubic inches
Optimal dimensions: x = and y = inches

static.solution: x^2y, and the constraints say that 4x+y=108, so V(x) = x^2(108-4x). We know x>0, also x\lt y=108-4x so 5x\lt 108, hence x\lt 21.6. Thus the domain of V is (0,21.6). Note that V'(x)=216x-12x^2=12x(18-x), so V'(x)>0 and V is increasing when 0\lt x\lt 18, and V'(x)\lt 0 and V is decreasing when 18\lt x. Thus the maximum volume occurs when x=18 and y=36, giving a maximum of 11664 cubic inches.

statement.p: An open box is to be made out of a 12-inch by 17-inch piece of cardboard by cutting out squares of equal size from the four corners and bending up the sides. If the box needs to be at least 1 inch deep, and no more than 3 inches deep, find the absolute maximum and absolute minimum volumes.
Maximum volume: Minimum volume:

solution.p: You have a rectangle of size 12 by 17, and you cut a square out of each corner. Say each square has length x. Then when you fold the rectangle up, the height of the resulting box is x and the length is 17-2 x while the width is 12 -2 x. So the volume of the box is V=l \cdot w \cdot h = (17 -2 x) (12 -2 x)x= (204-58 x +4 x^2)x=204 x-58 x^2+4x^3 Taking the derivative and setting it equal to 0 gives V'=204-2\cdot 58 x+ 12x^2 =0 Using the quadratic formula, we get that x=\frac{2\cdot58\pm\sqrt{4\cdot58^2-4\cdot 12\cdot 204}}{2\cdot 12}= 2.31121 \mbox{ or } 7.35545765840359 But if x=7.35545765840359, then the width of the box, which is 12-2 x, is negative. So the height is x=2.31121.

Plugging back in, the length of the box is 17-2x=17-2\cdot2.31121=12.3776 and the width is 12-2x=12-2\cdot2.31121=7.37758 And so the volume at the local extremum is 12.3776 \cdot 7.37758 \cdot 2.31121 = 211.052.
We also calculate the volume at the endpoints, x=1 and x=3. (17-2)(12-2)\cdot 1 = 150, \mbox{ and } (17-6)(12-6)\cdot 3 = 198
So the absolute maximum of volume is 211.052 and the absolute minimum of volume is 150.

statement.p: Find two numbers differing by 30 whose product is as small as possible.

The two numbers are .

solution.p: We are trying to find two numbers x and y such that their product P=xy is at a minimum, and we are also given that x-y=30. Solve for one of the variables, say x= 30+y. Substitute back into the product equation to get P= (30+y)y=30 y +y^2 Since we're trying to find a minimum, take the derivative and set it equal to 0. P'= 30+ 2y =0 Thus y=\frac{-30}{2}=-15.
We already said above that x= 30+y, so x=30+( -15)=15.

statement.p: A javalina rancher wants to enclose a rectangular area and then divide it into six pens with fencing parallel to one side of the rectangle (see the figure below). There are 780 feet of fencing available to complete the job. What is the largest possible total area of the six pens?
Largest area = ft^2

A fence is to be built to enclose a rectangular area of 230 square feet. The fence along three sides is to be made of material that costs 4 dollars per foot, and the material for the fourth side costs 12 dollars per foot. Find the dimensions of the enclosure that is most economical to construct.
Dimensions: x

solution.p: A rectangle has sides x and y. Since the names of the variables don't matter, say one of the y sides costs 12 dollars per foot and the other one and the two sides of length x all cost 4 dollars per square foot. Then the total cost of the fencing is C=4 x + 4 x + 4 y + 12 y= 8 x + 16 y We are trying to minimize this function, but we need to reduce it to one variable. However, we are also given that the area of this rectangle is 230. Thus, xy=230, and solving for one of the variables, y=\frac{230}{x}.

Substituting back into the cost function, we get C= 8 x+ 16 \left(\frac{230}{x} \right) = 8 x+ 3680 x^{-1} Take the derivative and set it equal to 0. C'=8 - 3680 x^{-2}= 8 + \frac{-3680}{x^2}=0 Multiply both sides by x^2 8 x^2-3680=0 and solve x=\sqrt{\frac{3680}{8}}=21.4476105895272 \mbox{ ft.} (Why didn't I know that it wasn't x=-\sqrt{\frac{3680}{8}}=-21.4476105895272 ? )

statement.p: The top and bottom margins of a poster are 4 cm and the side margins are each 2 cm. If the area of printed material on the poster is fixed at 384 square centimeters, find the dimensions of the poster with the smallest area.
Width = cm
Height = cm
If 1300 square centimeters of material is available to make a box with a square base and an open top, find the largest possible volume of the box.
Volume = cm^3

solution.p: To solve this problem, we will need to write a formula for the volume of the box in terms of one of its dimensions, and then use derivatives to find the dimensions at which the box has a maximum volume. Let x be the length of the sides of the square base. Then, if h is the height of the box, the volume is given by x^2h. We need to find an expression for the height h in terms of x.

This is where we use our information about the amount of material used in constructing the box. If the base of the box has sides of length x, then x^2 square centimeters of material are used to make the base. Therefore, we have only 1300 - x^2 square centimeters of material left to make the sides, of which there are four. Each of the sides uses hx square centimeters of material. Therefore, we get the formula:
Plugging this into our formula for volume, we can now write out v(x) as:

Now, we take the derivative of this expression, using the rules for taking derivatives of polynomials, to get v'(x) = \frac{1300}{4} - \frac{3}{4}x^2. Setting this equal to 0 will give us the critical points. When solving, remember that this is a real world situation, so we can not have a negative value for x (which is a length).
Now, plugging this width into our formula for volume, v(x), we get the maximal volume of v(20.82) = 4510.28.

statement.p: A piece of wire 35 m long is cut into two pieces. One piece is bent into a square and the other is bent into a circle.
(a) How much of the wire should go to the square to maximize the total area enclosed by both figures?
m
(b) How much of the wire should go to the square to minimize the total area enclosed by both figures?
m
Suppose that 524 ft of fencing are used to enclose a corral in the shape of a rectangle with a semicircle whose diameter is a side of the rectangle as the following figure:
Find the dimensions of the corral with maximum area.
x = ft.
y = ft.

static.solution:
Solution:
From the picture, we see that x is the width of the corral, and therefore the diameter of the semicircle,
and that y is the height of the rectangular section. Thus the perimeter of the corral can be expressed
by the equation 2y+ x+ \frac{\pi}{2}x= 2y + (1+ \frac{\pi}{2})x= 524 ft or equivalently,
y=\frac{1}{2}(524 - (1+ \frac{\pi}{2})x). Since x and y must both be nonnegative, it follows that x must
be restricted to the interval [0, \frac{524}{1+ \pi/2}]. The area of the corral is the sum of the area of the
rectangle and semicircle, A= xy + \frac{\pi}{8}x^2. Making the substitution for y from the
constraint equation,
A(x)=\frac{1}{2}x(524 - (1+ \frac{\pi}{2})x) + \frac{\pi}{8}x^2 = 262 x - \frac{1}{2}(1+ \frac{\pi}{2})x^2 + \frac{\pi}{8}x^2.
Now, A'(x) = 262 - (1 + \frac{\pi}{2})x + \frac{\pi}{4}x = 0 implies x= \frac{262}{(1+ \frac{\pi}{4})} \approx 146.745978220028.
With A(0)=0,
A(\frac{262}{(1+ \frac{\pi}{4})}) \approx 19223.7231468237 \qquad and \qquad A(\frac{524}{1+ \frac{\pi}{2}}) \approx 16315.0015073775,
it follows that the corral of maximum area has dimentions
x= \frac{262}{1+ \frac{\pi}{4}} \qquad and \qquad y= \frac{1}{2}(524 - (1+ \frac{\pi}{2}) \frac{262}{1+ \frac{\pi}{4}}) \approx 73.372989110014.

statement.p: This problem will lead you through the steps to answer this question:

A spherical balloon is being inflated at a constant rate of 20 cubic inches per second. How fast is the radius of the balloon changing at the instant the balloon's diameter is 12 inches? Is the radius changing more rapidly when d = 12 or when d = 16? Why?

Draw several spheres with different radii, and observe that as volume changes, the radius, diameter, and surface area of the balloon also change. Recall that the volume of a sphere of radius r is V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3. Note that in the setting of this problem, both V and r are changing as time t changes, and thus both V and r may be viewed as implicit functions of t, with respective derivatives \frac{dV}{dt} and \frac{dr}{dt}.
Differentiate both sides of the equation V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 with respect to t (using the chain rule on the right) to find a formula for \frac{dV}{dt} that depends on both r and \frac{dr}{dt}.

At this point in the problem, by differentiating we have "related the rates" of change of V and r. Recall that we are given in the problem that the balloon is being inflated at a constant rate of 20 cubic inches per second. To which derivative does this rate correspond?

From the above discussion, we know the value of \frac{dV}{dt} at every value of t. Next, observe that when the diameter of the balloon is 12, we know the value of the radius. In the equation \displaystyle{\frac{dV}{dt} = 4\pi r^2 \frac{dr}{dt}}, substitute these values for the relevant quantities and solve for the remaining unknown quantity, which is \frac{dr}{dt}. How fast is the radius changing at the instant when d = 12?
How fast is the radius changing at the instant when d = 16?
When is the radius changing more rapidly, when d = 12 or when d = 16?

li.p: C. Neither; the rate of change of the radius is constant

static.solution: t gives \displaystyle{\frac{dV}{dt} = 4\pi r^2 \frac{dr}{dt}}. Since dV/dt = 20, we can use the values r=6 and r=8 in this equation to obtain the solutions dr/dt = 0.0442097 and dr/dt = 0.024868, respectively. So the radius changes more rapidly when d=12.

statement.p: If \displaystyle L=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}, \ \ \frac {dx}{dt}=-1, \ \mbox{and } \frac {dy}{dt}=3, find \displaystyle\frac{dL}{dt} when x=7 and y=7.
\displaystyle\frac{dL}{dt} =

solution.p: We rewrite L=(x^2+y^2)^\frac{1}{2} and then take the derivative of both sides with respect to t. \frac{dL}{dt}=\frac{1}{2}\left(x^2+y^2\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}\left(2x \frac{dx}{dt}+2y\frac{dy}{dt}\right) Then we substitute what we know and solve for what we don't know. \frac{dL}{dt}=\frac{1}{2}\left(7^2+7^2\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}\left(2\cdot7 \cdot -1+2\cdot7\cdot3\right)=1.41421356237309.

statement.p: Suppose that water is pouring into a swimming pool in the shape of a right circular cylinder at a constant rate of 3 cubic feet per minute. If the pool has radius 3 feet and height 12 feet, what is the rate of change of the height of the water in the pool when the depth of the water in the pool is 9 feet?
ft/min

You say goodbye to your friend at the intersection of two perpendicular roads. At time t=0 you drive off North at a (constant) speed v and your friend drives West at a (constant) speed w. You badly want to know: how fast is the distance between you and your friend increasing at time t?
Enter here the derivative of the distance from your friend with respect to t:
Being scientifically minded you ask yourself how does the speed of separation change with time. In other words, what is the second derivative of the distance between you and your friend?
Oil spilled from a ruptured tanker spreads in a circle whose area increases at a constant rate of 6 {\rm mi}^2{\rm /hr}. How rapidly is radius of the spill increasing when the area is 6 {\rm mi}^2?
The radius is increasing at mi/hr.

solution.p: The area of a circle is A=\pi r^2. So taking the derivative of both sides we get \frac{dA}{dt}=2 \pi r \frac{dr}{dt} We are looking for \frac{dr}{dt}, and we are given that \frac{dA}{dt}=6, so we need to find r. But we know that A= 6, so 6=\pi r^2 and thus r=\sqrt{\frac{6}{\pi}}=1.38198 Substituting back in to \frac{dA}{dt}=2 \pi r \frac{dr}{dt} we get 6=2\pi \cdot 1.38198 \frac{dr}{dt} and thus \frac{dr}{dt}= \frac{6}{2\pi \cdot 1.38198 }=0.690988

statement.p: A 14 foot ladder is leaning against a wall.
If the top slips down the wall at a rate of 2 ft/s, how fast will the foot be moving away from the wall when the top is 13 feet above the ground?
The foot will be moving at ft/s.

solution.p: A ladder leaning against a wall forms a triangle, with the ladder being the hypotenuse z, the wall up to the top of the ladder forming one side x, and the floor from the wall to the ladder the third side y. Pythagorean's theorem relates the lengths of these sides, x^2+y^2=z^2 But the hypotenuse is a constant length - the ladder is sliding down the wall, not growing or shrinking, so z=14, and x^2+y^2=14^2. Thus differentiating both sides gives 2x \frac{dx}{dt} + 2y \frac{dy}{dt} = 0 We are told that the top is sliding down the wall, so side y is decreasing at the rate of 2, which means that \frac{dy}{dt}=-2, and we are looking for the rate at which the bottom is moving away from the wall, which is \frac{dx}{dt}. We are also given that y=13, so we still need to find x.
Substituting back into the original equation, x^2+13^2=14^2, so x=\sqrt{14^2-13^2}=5.19615242270663.
Finally, back to the derivative equation, 2\cdot5.19615242270663 \frac{dx}{dt} + 2\cdot (-13) \cdot 2 = 0 so \frac{dx}{dt}=\frac{13 \cdot 2}{5.19615242270663}=5.00370233297676

statement.p: A voltage V across a resistance R generates a current I=V/R. If a constant voltage of 13 volts is put across a resistance that is increasing at a rate of 0.6 ohms per second when the resistance is 6 ohms, at what rate is the current changing?
rate =

static.solution: dR/dt=0.6 when R=5 and V=9 and we want to know dI/dt. Differentiating I=V/R with V constant gives \frac{dI}{dt}=V\left(-\frac{1}{R^2}\frac{dR}{dt}\right), so substituting gives \frac{dI}{dt}=13\left(-\frac{1}{6^2}\cdot 0.6\right) \approx -0.2167 \hbox{ amp/s }. (Note that we know the units are amp/s from the Leibnitz form of the derivative, dI\over dt. It is, of course, equally correct to use the expression on the right-hand side to determine the units, \left(\frac{\hbox{V}}{\hbox{ohm}{}^2}\right)\left(\frac{\hbox{ohm}}{\hbox{s}}\right), or, in homework-friendly form, V/ohm*s.)

statement.p: When air expands adiabatically (without gaining or losing heat), its pressure P and volume V are related by the equation PV^{1.4}=C where C is a constant. Suppose that at a certain instant the volume is 540 cubic centimeters and the pressure is 83 kPa and is decreasing at a rate of 7 kPa/minute. At what rate in cubic centimeters per minute is the volume increasing at this instant?
Answer:
Note: Pa stands for Pascal. One Pa is equivalent to one \textrm{Newton}/\textrm{m}^2. kPa is a kiloPascal or 1000 Pascals.

Water is leaking out of an inverted conical tank at a rate of 12300.0 \textrm{cm}^3/\textrm{min} at the same time that water is being pumped into the tank at a constant rate. The tank has height 15.0 \ \textrm{m} and the the diameter at the top is 5.0 \ \textrm{m}. If the water level is rising at a rate of 20.0 \ \textrm{cm}/\textrm{min} when the height of the water is 4.5 \ \textrm{m}, find the rate at which water is being pumped into the tank in cubic centimeters per minute.
Answer: \textrm{cm}^3/\textrm{min}

static.hint: R be the unknown rate at which water is being pumped in. Then you know that if V is volume of water, \frac{dV}{dt}=R-12300.0. Use geometry (similar triangles) to find the relationship between the height of the water and the volume of the water at any given time. Recall that the volume of a cone with base radius r and height h is given by \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h

solution.p: The volume V of a cone of diameter d and height h is V=\frac{\pi d^2 h }{12}. We might as well do this problem a little more generally than stated. (It actually makes things clearer to use variables throughout and substitute specific values only at the end.) So suppose the diameter of our tank is D and its height is H. Suppose the depth of the water is h and the radius of the surface is r. Then, by similar triangles, \frac{r}{h} = \frac{R}{H}, or r= \frac{Rh}{H}. Substituting in the volume formula gives V= \frac{\pi D^2h^3}{12H^2}. Differentiating gives: V'= \frac{3\pi D^2h^2h'}{12H^2} = \frac{\pi D^2h^2h'}{4H^2} This rate of change in volume would be the rate T at which water is being pumped into the tank if there was no leak. However, if L is the leak rate then T = L+\frac{\pi D^2h^2h'}{4H^2}.
Note that since we have to have consistent units of length, and the answer is in cubic centimeters per minute, the lengths given in meters have to be converted to centimeters.
Thus, substituting L = 12300,\quad D = 500,\quad H = 1500, \quad h = 450,\quad h' = 20 we obtain T = 12300 + \frac{\pi*500^2*450^2*20}{4*1500^2} \approx 365729 \hbox{cm}^3/\hbox{min}.

A car comes to a stop six seconds after the driver applies the brakes. While the brakes are on, the following velocities are recorded:
Give lower and upper estimates (using all of the available data) for the distance the car traveled after the brakes were applied.
lower: ft
upper: ft
On a sketch of velocity against time, show the lower and upper estimates you found above..

solution.p: To find a lower estimate for the distance the car has traveled, we use the lowest velocity for each of the intervals 0\le t\le 2, 2\le t\le 4, and 4\le t\le 6 to calculate an estimated distance traveled in each interval. This gives \mbox{dist} = (50)(2) + (18)(2) + (0)(2) = 136. Similarly, for the upper estimate, we take the maximum velocity for each interval, to get \mbox{dist} = (99)(2) + (50)(2) + (18)(2) = 334.

Graphically, each of the terms in these sums is the area of a rectangle, as shown outlined in blue in the figures below. The lower- and upper estimates are the sum of the areas of these rectangles. (Note that the height of the last rectangle for the lower estimate is zero, so it does not contribute to the sum.)

distance = m

solution.p: A graph of the velocity is

solution.p: The distance traveled is just the area under the curve, which is the area of a right triangle. Thus the distance traveled is \mbox{distance} = \frac12 (\mbox{base}) (\mbox{height}) = \frac12 (10) (30) = 150.

statement.p: The velocity of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by f(t) = 6 - 2 t cm/sec. Use a graph of f(t) to find the exact change in position of the particle from time t=0 to t=4 seconds.
change in position = cm

solution.p: A graph of the velocity is

solution.p: The distance traveled is just the area under the curve. Note that in this case, this includes positive area (that above the t-axis), indicating forward motion, and negative area (that below the t-axis), indicating backward motion. The exact change in position is therefore \Delta \mbox{position} = \frac12(3)(6) - \frac12(1)(2) = 8.

A person walking along a straight path has her velocity in miles per hour at time t given by the function v(t) = 0.25t^3 - 1.5t^2 + 3t + 0.25, for times in the interval 0 \leq t \leq 2. The graph of this function is also given in each of the three diagrams below.

statement.p: Coal gas is produced at a gasworks. Pollutants in the gas are removed by scrubbers, which become less and less efficient as time goes on. The following measurements, made at the start of each month, show the rate at which pollutants are escaping (in tons/month) in the gas:
A. Make an overestimate and an underestimate of the total quantity of pollutants that escape during the first month.
overestimate = tons
underestimate = tons
B. Make an overestimate and an underestimate of the total quantity of pollutants that escape for the whole six months for which we have data.
overestimate =
underestimate =

solution.p: A. An overestimate is 9 tons (= 9\mbox{ tons/month}\cdot 1\mbox{ month}). An underestimate is 8 tons.

B. An overestimate is 129 tons. An underestimate is 100 tons. (The overestimate is \int_0^6 \mbox{rate} dt \approx (1)(9) + (1)(13) + (1)(18) + (1)(23) + (1)(29) + (1)(37) = 129, and similarly the underesimate is \int_0^6 \mbox{rate} dt \approx (1)(8) + (1)(9) + (1)(13) + (1)(18) + (1)(23) + (1)(29) = 100.)

statement.p: The following table gives the the approximate amount of emissions, E, of nitrogen oxides in millions of metric tons per year in the US. Let t be the number of years since 1940 and E=f(t).
Estimate the integral: \int_0^{50}{f(t)dt} \approx

p.em: Be sure that you know what the units of your answer are, and what its meaning is!
(Original data from the Statistical Abstract of the US, 1992)

solution.p: The integral \int_0^{50}{f(t)dt} represents the total emissions of nitrogen oxides, in millions of metric tons, during the period 1940 to 1990.

We estimate the integral using left- and right-hand sums: \mbox{Left sum} = (6.4)(10) + (9.6)(10) + (12.7)(10) + (18)(10) + (20.4)(10) = 671, and \mbox{Right sum} = (9.6)(10) + (12.7)(10) + (18)(10) + (20.4)(10) + (19.9)(10) = 806. We can then average the left- and right-hand sums to find the best estimate of the integral: \int_0^{50}{f(t)dt} \approx {{671 + 806} \over 2} = 738.5 \mbox{ million metric tons.} Between 1940 and 1990, about 738.5 million metric tons of nitrogen oxides were emitted.

Is the following statement true? \hbox{Average}(f)\cdot\hbox{Average(g)} = \hbox{Average}(f\cdot g)
Yes
No

static.solution:
\int_0^2\,f(x)\,dx and \int_0^2\,g(x)\,dx as the area under the curves and dividing by the length of the interval, which is 2. This gives us:
\hbox{Average}(f) = 0.25, and
\hbox{Average}(g) = 0.25.
However, when we find f(x)\cdot g(x), we find that the product is everywhere zero! g(x) is zero for 0\le x\le 1, so f(x)\cdot g(x) is zero there, and g(x) is zero for 1\le x\le 2, so f(x)\cdot g(x) is zero there too. Thus the average value of the product is zero, and the average of the product is not equal to the product of the averages!

Evaluate exactly, using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus:

static.solution: e^x is e^x, so an antiderivative of 8 e^x is 8 e^x, and we get \int_0^{b} 8 e^x dx = 8 e^x\big|_0^{b} = 8 e^{b} - 8 e^0 = 8 e^{b} - 8.

statement.p: Evaluate the definite integral \int_{ 0 } ^ { \pi } 10 \sin(x) dx

solution.p: This integration can be done because we know that the derivative with respect to x of \cos(x) is -\sin(x). So we obtain a -\sin(x) inside the integral, and we can then integrate to obtain \cos(x). Of course, since there isn't a minus sign inside the integral, we'll have to multiply inside and outside by -1 (which doesn't change the value of course): \begin{aligned} \int_0^\pi 10 \sin(x) dx \amp = -10 \int_0^\pi (-\sin(x)) dx \\ \amp = -10 \left( \cos(x) \bigg|_0^\pi \right) \\ \amp = -10 ( \cos(\pi) - \cos(0) ) = -10 (-1-1) = 2 \cdot 10 = 20 \end{aligned}

statement.p: Evaluate the definite integral:
Use the Fundamental Theorem to determine the value of b if the area under the graph of f(x) = 3 x between x = 1 and x = b is equal to 12. Assume b>1.

static.solution: f(x) = 3 x between x=1 and x = b is given by \int_1^b (3 x) dx. Using the Fundamental Theorem to evaluate the integral: \hbox{Area } = \frac{3}{2} x^2 \bigg|_1^b = \frac{3}{2} b^2 - \frac{3}{2}. Since the area is 12, we have \frac{3}{2} b^2 - \frac{3}{2} = 12, so \frac{3}{2} b^2 = \frac{27}{2}, and thus b^2 = 9,\quad\hbox{or}\quad b = \pm 3. Since b is larger than 1, we have b = 3.

f concave up on f concave down on

minimum(s) at x= maximum(s) at x=
d. Recall that the Total Change Theorem tells us that f(1) - f(0) = \int_0^1 f'(x) \, dx. What is the exact value of f(1)?
e. Use the given information and similar reasoning to that in (d) to determine the exact value of f(2), f(3), f(4), f(5), and f(6).

Based on your responses to all of the preceding questions, which of the following is an accurate graph of y=f(x)?
?
A
B

solution.p: a. The function f is increasing where its derivative f' (as shown in the graph) is positive, or above the x-axis, so \left(0,1.5\right)\cup \left(4,6\right). The function f is decreasing where its derivative f' is negative, or below the x-axis, so \left(1.5,4\right).

b. The function f is concave up where its derivative f' is increasing, so \left(0,1\right)\cup \left(3,5\right). The function f is concave down where its derivative f' is decreasing, so \left(1,3\right)\cup \left(5,6\right).

c. By the First Derivative Test, the function f has a minimum where its derivative f'=0 (so crosses the x-axes) and changed from negative to positive, so x=4. By the First Derivative Test, the function f has a maximum where its derivative f'=0 (so crosses the x-axes) and changed from positive to negative, so x=1.5.

d. We use geometry to calculate the (signed) area to see that \int_0^1 f'(x) \, dx = \frac{1}{2}, and we were given that f(0)=1, so f(1) - f(0) = \int_0^1 f'(x) \, dx means f(1) - 1= \frac{1}{2}, so f(1) = 1.5.

Similarly, f(2) - f(0) = \int_0^2 f'(x) \, dx, and using geometry, remembering that below the x-axis counts negatively, we see that \int_0^2 f'(x) \, dx = \frac{1}{2}, and so f(2) = 1.5. And continue in this way to calculate that f(3) = -0.5, f(4) = -2, f(5) = -0.5, f(6) = 1.

p.em: (Click on the graph for a larger version.)

statement.p: Sketch, on a sheet of work paper, an accurate graph of f, and use it to find each of
and
Then find the value of the integral:

p.em: (Note that you can do this in two different ways!)

static.solution:
x=5, we are given that f(5)=0. Moving to the left on the interval 4 \lt x \lt 5, we have f'(x) = 3, and we can find f(4) by knowing that the change in f(x) over this interval is equal to the area under f'(x) between x=4 and x=5. Thus f(5) - f(4) = (3)(1), so that f(4) = f(5) - (1)(3) = -3. Similarly, continuing back to x=0, f(0) = f(4) - (1)(-1) - (1)(2) - (1)(-1) - (1)(2) = -5
Moving to the right from x=5, we know that f'(x) = -1 on 5 \lt x \lt 7. So, as before, f(7) = f(5) + (2)(-1) = -2. Similarly, continuing to x=7, f(7) = f(7) = -2.
Then, the value of the integral \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx is given by the sum \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx = (2)(1) + (-1)(1) + (2)(1) + (-1)(1) + (3)(1) + (-1)(2) = 3.
Alternatively, knowing f(7)=-2 and f(0)=-5 and using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, we have \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx=f(7)-f(0) = (-2) - (-5) = 3.

statement.p: At which of the marked values of x is
A. f(x) greatest? x =
B. f(x) least? x =
C. f'(x) greatest? x =
D. f'(x) least? x =
E. f''(x) greatest? x =
F. f''(x) least? x =

static.solution:
A,B. Since f' is everywhere positive, f is everywhere increasing. Hence the greatest value of f is at F and the least value of f is at A.
C,D. Directly from the graph, we see that f' is greatest at B and least at D.
E,F. Since f'' gives the slope of the graph of f', f'' is greatest where f' is rising most rapidly, namely at A, and f'' is least where f' is falling most rapidly, namely at C.

statement.p: Consider the function A defined by the rule A(x) = \int_1^x f(t) \, dt, where f(t) = 4-2t.
a. Compute A(1) and A(2) exactly.
b. Use the First Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to find an equivalent formula for A(x) that does not involve integrals. That is, use the first FTC to evaluate \int_1^x (4-2t) \, dt.
c. Observe that f is a linear function; what kind of function is A?
d. Using the formula you found in (b) that does not involve integrals, compute A'(x).
e. While we have defined f by the rule f(t) = 4-2t, it is equivalent to say that f is given by the rule f(x) = 4 - 2x. What do you observe about the relationship between A and f?

li.p: A is an antiderivative of f
A is a derivative of f
A is a multiple of f

solution.p: a. We were given that A(x) = \int_1^x f(t) \, dt, so A(1) = \int_1^1 f(t) \, dt =0.
c. 4x-x^{2}-3 is a quadratic function.
d. The derivative of 4x-x^{2}-3 is 4-2x.
e. Thus, the derivative of A is f, or A'=f, so A is an antiderivative of f.

In Section 2.5, we learned the Chain Rule and how it can be applied to find the derivative of a composite function. In particular, if u is a differentiable function of x, and f is a differentiable function of u(x), then \frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(u(x)) \right] = f'(u(x)) \cdot u'(x). In words, we say that the derivative of a composite function c(x) = f(u(x)), where f is considered the "outer" function and u the "inner" function, is "the derivative of the outer function, evaluated at the inner function, times the derivative of the inner function."

(a) For each of the following functions, use the Chain Rule to find the function's derivative. Notice the label of each derivative respects the functions name (e.g., the derivative of g(x) should be labeled g'(x)).

(iv) If q(x) = (2-7x)^4, then q'(x) =
(v) If r(x) = 3^{4-11x}, then r'(x) =

(b) For each of the following functions, use your work in (a) to help you determine the general antiderivative of the function. (Recall that the general antiderivative of a function includes +C to reflect the entire family of functions that share the same derivative.) Notice the label of each antiderivative respects the name (e.g., the antiderivative of m should be called M). Remember that you can check your work by computing the derivative of each proposed antiderivative.

(ii) If n(x) = \cos(5x+1), then N(x) =

(iv) If v(x) = (2-7x)^3, then V(x) =
(v) If w(x) = 3^{4-11x}, then W(x) =
(c) Based on your experience in parts (a) and (b), conjecture an antiderivative for each of the following functions. Test your conjectures by computing the derivative of each proposed antiderivative.
(i) a(x) = \cos(\pi x), then A(x)=
(iii) c(x) = xe^{x^2}, then C(x)=

solution.p: a. (i) The derivative of g(x) = e^{3x} is g'(x) = 3e^{3x}\ln\mathopen{}\left(e\right).
(ii) The derivative of h(x) = \sin(5x+1) is h'(x) = 5\cos\mathopen{}\left(5x+1\right).
(iii) The derivative of p(x) = \arctan(2x) is p'(x) = 2\frac{1}{1+\left(2x\right)^{2}}.
(iv) The derivative of q(x) = (2-7x)^4 is q'(x) = -7\cdot 4\mathopen{}\left(2-7x\right)^{3}.
(v) The derivative of r(x) = 3^{4-11x} is r'(x) = -11\ln\mathopen{}\left(3\right)\cdot 3^{4-11x}.
b. (i) The general antiderivative of m(x) = e^{3x} is \frac{1}{3} e^{3x}, because the derivative of \frac{1}{3}e^{3x}+C is e^{3x}.
(ii) The general antiderivative of n(x) = \cos(5x+1) is \frac{1}{5}\sin\mathopen{}\left(5x+1\right)+C, because the derivative of \frac{1}{5}\sin\mathopen{}\left(5x+1\right)+C is n(x) = \cos(5x+1).
(iii) The general antiderivative of \displaystyle s(x) = \frac{1}{1+4x^2} is \frac{1}{2}\tan^{-1}\mathopen{}\left(2x\right)+C.
(iv) The general antiderivative of v(x) = (2-7x)^3 is \frac{1}{-7\cdot 4} (2-7x)^4+C;
(v) The general antiderivative of w(x) = 3^{4-11x} is \frac{1}{\ln(3)\cdot(-11)} 3^{4-11x}+C;
(c) (i) The general antiderivative of a(x) = \cos(\pi x) is \frac{1}{\pi }\sin\mathopen{}\left(\pi x\right)+C;
(ii) The general antiderivative of b(x) = (4x+7)^{11} is \frac{1}{4\cdot 12} (4x+7)^{12} +C;
(iii) The general antiderivative of c(x) = xe^{x^2} is \frac{1}{2}e^{x^{2}}+C;

statement.p: Solve the integral below with u-substitution. \int \frac{2 \sec(10 x)\tan(10 x)}{\sec^{9}(10 x)} \, dx
Let u =
Then du =
Then, we substitute in the integral to get \displaystyle \int , (which has 'u' and 'du' in it, not 'x' or 'dx'. )
Now this is a basic integral. Evaluate it to get all possible antiderivatives in terms of 'u':
and then the final answer is \displaystyle \int \frac{2 \sec(10 x)\tan(10 x)}{\sec^{9}(10 x)} \, dx \, =

hint.p: Remember that the derivative of \sec x is \sec x \tan x.
Let u = \sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right). Don't forget the chain rule when you find du.
Remember that to integrate something of the form \displaystyle \frac{1}{u^9} you should rewrite as u^{-9} and then use power rule.

solution.p: Let u=\sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right). Then we take the derivative of both sides to get du = 10\sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right)\tan\mathopen{}\left(10x\right) \, dx

You can do the next step in different ways, but one way is to solve for dx. Since du = 10\sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right)\tan\mathopen{}\left(10x\right) \, dx, we divide over to get that dx=\frac{1}{10\sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right)\tan\mathopen{}\left(10x\right)} \, du Then we substitute back into the original integral. \int \frac{2 \sec(10 x)\tan(10 x)}{\sec^{9}(10 x)} \, dx = \int \frac{2 \sec(10 x)\tan(10 x)}{u^{9}} \frac{1}{10\sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right)\tan\mathopen{}\left(10x\right)} \, du Which simplifies to \int \frac{0.2}{u^{9}}du

Now, this is one of our basic integrals because we can write it as \displaystyle \int 0.2 u^{-9} \, du and thus we can integrate it. Constants in front just stay multiplied so we get \int 0.2 u^{-9} \, du = \frac{0.2}{-8} u^{-8}+C Finally, make sure you put it back in terms of the original variable, which in this case is 'x'. So we substitute back in for 'u', which was \sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right). Thus the final answer to this integral is \int \frac{2 \sec(10 x)\tan(10 x)}{\sec^{9}(10 x)} \, dx = -0.025\mathopen{}\left(\sec\mathopen{}\left(10x\right)\right)^{-8}+C

You can do the next step in different ways, but one way is to solve for dx. Since du = 2\csc^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-2x\right) \, dx, we divide over to get that dx=\frac{1}{2\csc^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-2x\right)} \, du Then we substitute back into the original integral. \int 6 \csc^2(-2 x) e^{\cot(-2 x)} \, dx = \int 6 \csc^2(-2 x) e^{u} \frac{1}{2\csc^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-2x\right)} \, du Which simplifies to \int 3e^{u}du

Now, this is one of our basic integrals, and we can integrate it. Constants in front just stay multiplied so we get \int 3e^{u}du = 3e^{u}+C Finally, make sure you put it back in terms of the original variable, which in this case is 'x'. So we substitute back in for 'u', which was \cot\mathopen{}\left(-2x\right). Thus the final answer to this integral is \int 6 \csc^2(-2 x) e^{\cot(-2 x)} \, dx = 3e^{\cot\mathopen{}\left(-2x\right)}+C

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.
Find the the general antiderivative F(x) of the function f(x) given below. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.
antiderivative F(x) =

static.solution: \int\,6 x \cos(x^{2})\,dx. We use substitution with w = x^{2} to find this. We have dw = 2\,x\,dx, so that \int\,6 x \cos(x^{2})\,dx = 3\int\,\cos(w)\,dw = 3\,\sin(w) + C = 3\,\sin(x^{2}) + C.

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.

static.solution: w = \ln(z). Then dw = \frac{1}{z}\,dz, so that \int\,\frac{\ln(z)^{4}}{z}\,dz = \int\,w^{4}\,dw = {1\over 5}\,w^{5} + C = {1\over 5}\,(\ln(z))^{5} + C.

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.

static.solution: w = e^{3 x} + 9. Then dw = 3\,e^{3 x}\,dx, so that \int\,\frac{e^{3 x}}{9 + e^{3 x}}\,dx = {1\over 3}\int\,{1\over w}\,dw = {1\over 3}\,\ln(|w|) + C = {1\over 3}\,\ln(|e^{3 x} + 9|) + C. Because e^{3 x} + 9 is always positive, we can drop the absolute values from the argument of the natural log.

statement.p: Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to find

static.solution: w = -\cos\mathopen{}\left(q\right), so that dw = \sin\mathopen{}\left(q\right)\,dq. Then w(3\pi) = 1 and w(3\pi/2) = 0, so that \int_{3\pi}^{3\pi/2}\, e^{-\cos\mathopen{}\left(q\right)}\cdot \sin\mathopen{}\left(q\right) \,dq = \int_1^0\,e^w\,dw = e^w\bigg|_1^0 = 1 - e.

statement.p: Consider the integral \displaystyle \int\,6\,x\,(x^{2} + 1)\,dx. In the following, we will evaluate the integral using two methods.
A. First, rewrite the integral by multiplying out the integrand:
Then evaluate the resulting integral term-by-term:
B. Next, rewrite the integral using the substitution w = x^{2} + 1:
Evaluate this integral (and back-substitute for w) to find the value of the original integral:
C. How are your expressions from parts (A) and (B) different? What is the difference between the two? (Ignore the constant of integration.)
(answer from B)-(answer from A) =
Are both of the answers correct? (Be sure you can explain why they are!)

static.solution:
A. \int\,6\,x\,(x^{2} + 1)\,dx = \int\,6\,x^{3} + 6\,x\,dx. Thus, antidifferentiating term-by-term, we get \int\,6\,x\,(x^{2} + 1)\,dx = {3\over2}\,x^{4} + 3\,x^{2} + C.
B. \int\,6\,x\,(x^{2} + 1)\,dx = \int\,3\,w\,dw. Thus, antidifferentiating, we get \int\,6\,x\,(x^{2} + 1)\,dx = {3\over2}\,w^2 + C = {3\over2}\,(x^{2} + 1)^2 + C.
C. To see the difference between these two answers, we expand the second: (x^{2} + 1)^2 = x^{4} + 2\,x^{2} + 1, so the difference is ({3\over2} (x^{4} + 2\,x^{2} + 1)) - ({3\over2} \,x^{4} + 3\,x^{2}) = {3\over2}. That is, the difference is a constant! This is completely reasonable: the antiderivative is only determined up to a constant, and the arbitrary constant C that we get for the most general antiderivative will adjust for this difference.

statement.p: Evaluate the indefinite integral \int {8 (1+\tan(t))^5 \sec^2(t)}\, dt

Evaluate the integral \int {10 \cot(x) \ln(\sin(x))}\, dx
Note: Use an upper-case "C" for the constant of integration.

In Section 2.3, we developed the Product Rule and studied how it is employed to differentiate a product of two functions. In particular, recall that if f and g are differentiable functions of x, then \frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(x) \cdot g(x) \right] = f(x) \cdot g'(x) + g(x) \cdot f'(x).
(a) For each of the following functions, use the Product Rule to find the function's derivative. Be sure to label each derivative by name (e.g., the derivative of g(x) should be labeled g'(x)).
(i) If g(x) = x\sin(x), then g'(x) =
(ii) If h(x) = xe^x, then h'(x) =
(iii) If p(x) = x\ln(x), then p'(x) =
(iv.) If q(x) = x^2 \cos(x) , then q'(x) =
(v.) If r(x) = e^x \sin(x) , then r'(x) =
(b) Use your work in (a) to help you evaluate the following indefinite integrals. Use differentiation to check your work.
(i) \displaystyle \int xe^x + e^x \, dx =
(ii) \displaystyle \int e^x(\sin(x) + \cos(x)) \, dx =
(iii) \displaystyle \int 2x\cos(x) - x^2 \sin(x) \, dx -
(iv) \displaystyle \int x\cos(x) + \sin(x) \, dx =
(v) \displaystyle \int 1 + \ln(x) \, dx =

(c) Observe that the examples in (b) work nicely because of the derivatives you were asked to calculate in (a). Each integrand in (b) is precisely the result of differentiating one of the products of basic functions found in (a). To see what happens when an integrand is still a product but not necessarily the result of differentiating an elementary product, we consider how to evaluate \int x\cos(x) \, dx.

(i) First, observe that \frac{d}{dx} \left[ x\sin(x) \right] = x\cos(x) + \sin(x). Integrating both sides indefinitely and using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals, we find that \int \left(\frac{d}{dx} \left[ x\sin(x) \right] \right) \, dx = \int x\cos(x) \, dx + \int \sin(x) \, dx. In this last equation, evaluate the indefinite integral on the left side.
In that same equation, now evaluate the indefinite integral all the way to the right side.
(ii) Using your answers to the previous two parts, solve the resulting equation for the expression \int x \cos(x) \, dx.
Calculate the following integral: \int x \cos(3 x) \, dx
We let u= and dv =
So \ \ \ du= and v =
and then use the integration-by-parts formula to find that
\displaystyle \int x \cos( 3 x) \, dx = - \displaystyle \int
and finally, we finish evaluating to get that \displaystyle \int x \cos( 3 x) dx =

hint.p: We pick u and dv so that dv can be integrated, while ideally, u gets simpler.
Both x and \cos\mathopen{}\left(3x\right) can be integrated, so we can choose for u to get simpler.

The derivative of x is 1 (which is of lower degree) while the derivative of \cos\mathopen{}\left(3x\right) is -3 \sin(3 x), (which is another trig function and not any simpler). Thus, we should let u=x and dv=\cos\mathopen{}\left(3x\right)dx.
Then du=dx and v=\frac{1}{3} \sin( 3 x).

Next, remember that the integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in what we already know are u, \ v,\ du and dv, we get that \int x \cos(3 x) \, dx = x \cdot \frac{1}{3}\sin(3 x) - \int \frac{1}{3}\sin(3 x) \, dx
Lastly, we integrate the second part, so the answer is \int x \cos(3 x) \, dx = \frac{1}{3} x \sin(3 x) + \frac{1}{9}\cos(3 x)+C

solution.p: Let u=x and dv=\cos\mathopen{}\left(3x\right)dx.
Then du=dx and v=\frac{1}{3} \sin(3 x).

The integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in, we get that \int x \cos(3 x) \, dx = x \cdot \frac{1}{3}\sin(3 x - \int \frac{1}{3}\sin(3 x) \cdot dx Lastly, we integrate the second part, so the answer is \int x \cos(3 x) \, dx = \frac{1}{3} x \sin(3 x) + \frac{1}{9}\cos(3 x)+C

We let u= and dv =
So \ \ \ du= and v =
and then use the integration-by-parts formula to find that
\displaystyle \int \sec^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-4x\right) x \, dx = - \displaystyle \int
and finally, we finish evaluating to get that \displaystyle \int \sec^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-4x\right) x \, dx =

hint.p: We pick u and dv so that dv can be integrated, and then (ideally) u gets simpler.
Both x and \sec^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-4x\right) can be easily integrated, so pick them so that u gets simpler.
Let u=x so du= dx.
Then dv =\sec^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-4x\right)dx, and we integrate to get that v= \frac{1}{-4} \tan(-4 x)
Remember that even though it's not Basic, you do know how to integrate \tan(-4 x). It's number 7 on the u-Substitution practice worksheet we did in class.

solution.p: Let u=x and dv=\sec^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-4x\right)dx.
Then du=dx and v=\frac{1}{-4} \tan(-4 x).

The integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in, we get that \int x \sec^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-4x\right) \, dx = x \cdot \frac{1}{-4} \tan(-4 x) - \int \frac{1}{-4} \tan(-4 x) \, dx =\frac{1}{-4} x \tan(-4 x) - \int \frac{1}{-4} \tan(-4 x) \, dx Unfortunately, the integral is not Basic, but we can rewrite it and integrate it using u-substitution. \frac{1}{-4} x \tan(-4 x) - \int \frac{1}{-4} \frac{\sin(-4 x)}{\cos(-4 x)} \, dx Let u=\cos(-4 x) so du = + 4 \sin(-4 x) \, dx and solving for dx gives us dx=\frac{du}{ + 4 \sin(-4 x)}.

Substituting back into the integral gives us: \int \frac{1}{-4} \frac{\sin(-4 x)}{\cos(-4 x)} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{-4} \frac{\sin(-4 x)}{u} \, \frac{du}{ + 4 \sin(-4 x)} = \int \frac{-1}{16} \frac{du}{u} This integrates to \frac{-1}{16} \ln(u) and substituting back in for u gives \frac{-1}{16} \ln(\cos(-4 x))+C Combining it with the non-integrated term from integration by parts, we get the final answer: \int x \sec^{2}\mathopen{}\left(-4x\right) \, dx = \frac{1}{-4} x \tan(-4 x) - \frac{-1}{16} \ln(\cos(-4 x))+C

statement.p: Calculate the following integral: \int x^{7} \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) \, dx
We let u= and dv =
So \ \ \ du= and v =
and then use the integration-by-parts formula to find that
\displaystyle \int x^{7} \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) \, dx = - \displaystyle \int
and finally, we finish evaluating to get that \displaystyle \int x^{7} \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) \, dx =

hint.p: We pick u and dv so that dv can be integrated, and then (ideally) u gets simpler.
We do not know how to easily integrate \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right), so that must be u.
Then everything else in the integral must equal dv. So dv =x^{7}dx.
Since u=\ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) we take the derivative to get that du= \frac{1}{x}dx =\frac{1}{x} \, dx.
Since dv =x^{7}dx we integrate to get that v= \frac{1}{8} x^{8}

Next, remember that the integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in what we already know are u, \ v,\ du and dv, we get that \int x^{7} \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) \, dx = \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) \cdot \frac{1}{8} x^{8} - \int \frac{1}{8} x^{8} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \, dx Now cancel the x's in that last integral, and it's a basic integral (power rule) so you can evaluate it.

solution.p: Let u=\ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) and dv=x^{7}dx.
Then du=\frac{1}{x}dx and v=\frac{1}{8} x^{8}.

The integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in, we get that \int x^7 \ln(-5 x) \, dx = \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) \cdot \frac{1}{8}x^{8} - \int \frac{1}{8}x^{8} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \, dx =\ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) \cdot \frac{1}{8}x^{8} - \int \frac{1}{8}x^{7} \, dx Lastly, we integrate the second part, so the answer is \int x^7 \ln(-5 x) \, dx = \frac{1}{8}x^{8} \cdot \ln\mathopen{}\left(-5x\right) - \frac{1}{64}x^{8}+C

statement.p: Use integration by parts to evaluate the integral.
If g(1)=-4, g(5)=4, and \displaystyle \int_1^5 \! g(x) \, dx = -8, evaluate the integral \displaystyle \int_1^5 \! x g'(x)\, dx.
Answer:

solution.p: SOLUTION

Let u = x, \; dv = g'(x) \, dx \; \Rightarrow \; du = dx, \; v = g(x). We then have \int_1^5 \! x g'(x)\, dx = \Big[x g(x)\Big]_1^5 - \int_1^5 g(x) \, dx = \Big[ 5\cdot g(5) - 1 \cdot g(1) \Big] + 8 = 5\cdot (4) + 4 + 8 = 32

For each of the following integrals, indicate whether integration by substitution or integration by parts is more appropriate, or if neither method is appropriate. Do not evaluate the integrals.

static.solution:
w to be the argument of a function, etc., such that its derivative, dw = w'\,dx, appears in the integrand; or, if the function looks like one on which integration by parts is good. We see that:
1. For \int\,x\sin x\,dx, integration by parts is appropriate, because by taking u = x and v' = \sin(x), we end up with an integral that is easy to find.
2. For \int\,{x^{4}\over 1 + x^{5}}\,dx, substitution is appropriate, because by taking w=1 + x^{5} we get an integral we can find.
3. For \int\,x^{4} e^{x^{5}}\,dx, substitution is appropriate, because by taking w = x^{5} we get an integral we can find.
